dc:title: House of Hospitality Dorothy Day 1939, Chapter Nine, pp. 150 - 174. A summer full of trips between the Easton farm and the city, she vividly chronicles the flurry of activity that seemingly accomplishes a great deal. Struggles with issues of freedom, personal responsibility, and her role in the movement. Feels "utterly lacking, ineffective."
